description.narrative: The objective of the Second Participatory Rural Investment Project is to pilot the consolidation of institutional arrangements between the national, prefecture and municipal governments and civil society for sustainable management of sub-national public investment in selected productive sectors with an emphasis on territorial development. There are 3 components to the project. Component 1 (Institutional Strengthening) will facilitate to increase the scale of planning, investments and O&M activities, while establishing clear and non-discretional rules for coordination and co-financing between prefectures and municipalities. Component 2 (Productive Investments) will provide support for the implementation of plans prepared under component 1. The component would provide national (IDA and bilateral) co-financing solely for eligible investments that fall under the competencies of municipal governments as well as for improving poor communities' access to productive assets. Component 3 (Project Management) will finance technical teams, studies, and related administrative costs which will support the operation of a National Operations Unit (NOU) integrated within VMD's structure, and up to nine Territorial Operating Units (TOU) in the departments of the Borrower.

condition.narrative: FPS shall have completed all SAP modifications agreed with the Association, pursuant to the FPS Action Plan.
FPS shall have completed the modifications of the first phase of SAP, agreed with the Association pursuant to the FPS Action Plan.
FPS shall have established its public web page with the register of companies, supervisors, and contracts awarded by FPS and theMunicipalities since January 31, 2008.
The Recipient and the Association shall assess semiannually, FPS institutional performance to confirm compliance with the FPSAction Plan.
The Recipient shall cause FPS to carry out the FPS Action Plan.
The Recipient shall maintain throughout the implementation of the Project: the control and monitoring unit under FPS€™s executiveoffice;the environmental unit; and the procurement monitoring unit

title.narrative: Technical and annual budget execution of the projectin accordance with the implementation plan, the operational manual, the resultsframework, and the donation and credit agreements
Timely and valid information is available for timely decision making and the adaptive management of the project.

81 subnational public entities have generated, agreed upon, and applied local and/or sectoral regulatory systems that regulate the implementation of instruments developed and applied by the project (r

comment.narrative: Exceeded. Based on a PDCR final report

title.narrative: 24,000 members of 180 subnational entities and civil society organizations have been trained and participate in the formulation, management, and evaluation of development plans, programs, and projects

target.value: 24,000 members of 180 subnational entities and civil have trained and 40% participate in the formulation, management, andevaluation of development plans, programs, and projects.

comment.narrative: Exceeded. Based on the PDCR final report

title.narrative: Increase of 30% in the value of production of families participating in micro-irrigation, promotion of economic activities, productive promotion subprojects.

target.value: Increase of 30% in the value of production of families participating in micro-irrigation, promotion of economic activities,productive promotion subprojects.

comment.narrative: Exceeded. But sample incomplete. Only includes a sample of 12 micro irrigation subprojects. The increase was (375%)

title.narrative: 20% increase in the sales value of products and services of project participants who benefit from economic promotion activities.

target.value: 20% increase in the sales value of products and services of project participants who benefit from economic promotion activities.

title.narrative: The PDCR#s technical and administrative staff is stable in terms of periodic performance assessments.

actual.value: Staff stability adequate in both Ministry of Autonomy and FPS.

comment.narrative: The project executed regular performance evaluations and based stffing decisions on them.

title.narrative: 15% increase in the executed budget of municipal governments and prefecture for productive investments in the project area.

comment.narrative: Not achieved. Reduction of the budget disbursed for productive investments from 29% to 23.2%, among the Municipalities within theproject area. Indicator beyond Project control.

title.narrative: 54 sectoral, multi-municipal and 18 territorial development programs &/or plans mutually agreed upon by the Prefecture, Municipal Governments, their associations, civil society actors, & other actors

comment.narrative: Substantially achieved. Diverse sources have financed the plan implementation

title.narrative: 30% increase in the benefits of public investments co-financed by the project.

baseline.value: 50 composite (based on a composite index of income, employment and production value)

target.value: 20% reduction in costs or 20% increase in the benefit

comment.narrative: An estimate for a sample of 10 irrigation subprojects is 477%. Sample size was small and incomplete. Subproject baselines had to bereconstructed and comparability with Project baseline not achieved. No control group.

title.narrative: Reduction of at least 30% in average travel time on roads assisted under the project.

baseline.value: Travel time to capital from Municipality - baseline average 128 in bus/taxi.

comment.narrative: Achieved, but measurement uncertainties. Based on the final survey.

title.narrative: 100% of productive investments executed by the project have been cofinanced by prefectures and/or municipalities, under the framework of their competencies.

comment.narrative: Achieved. 71 subprojects co-financed by the central government and both departmental and municipal governments; 173 subprojectsco-financed by the central Government and Municipalities

title.narrative: Validated models for ordering subnational public investment have been tested for replication in other sectors and territories.

comment.narrative: Achieved. 2 co-financing models were used and validated for the collaboration between sub-national governments (Cochabamba andOruro Departments). Relevance in new policy context to be seen,

title.narrative: 70% of the public investments cofinanced and coordinated by the project are properly maintained and operated

comment.narrative: Substantially achieved. Based on a sample of 81 subprojects (final survey). The Economic Evaluation revealed similar results for asample of 38 subprojects

title.narrative: 18 inter-municipal plans with a territorial focus have been consolidated as a mechanism for local development.

comment.narrative: Substantially achieved. Out of the 24 plans formulated for both territorial development and infrastructure improvement, 17 planshave been used as instruments to lead joint efforts among diverse actors such as Municipalities and Departmental Governments
